all_summaries: This paper introduces Contrastive Activation Addition (CAA) as a method to control text properties in adaptive free-form summarization, showing that steering vectors effectively influence topic focus, sentiment, and readability but degrade text quality at high steering strengths. It compares CAA with prompting, finding that prompting preserves quality better but offers weaker control, while combining methods achieves the best efficacy-quality trade-off. The study evaluates summaries on intrinsic and extrinsic quality, topical focus, sentiment, toxicity, and readability, revealing that toxicity steering is particularly challenging and often leads to text degradation. The authors conclude that hybrid approaches of steering and prompting are most effective for balancing control and quality in real-world applications.

The paper evaluates the effectiveness of steering vectors, particularly Contrastive Activation Addition (CAA), in adaptive free-form summarization, showing that CAA can control topical focus, sentiment, and readability but not toxicity. It finds that higher steering strengths degrade text quality, with a trade-off between control efficacy and summary quality. Prompting alone offers weaker control but better text quality, while combining steering and prompting provides the best balance. The study uses the NEWTS dataset and highlights challenges in steering toxicity and maintaining quality, suggesting hybrid approaches for practical applications. The study compares steering to prompting, finding that steering alone has limited effectiveness for toxicity but can influence other properties, while combining steering with prompting enhances control and quality trade-offs.
